comments:
I created a new Web Project but was unable to set a target runtime (I assume you
guys are working on that, so I didn't open a bug on that.). On the new project,
I opened the project properties and set the server target runtime to Tomcat v5.0
with jdk142.

Next, I created a simple Java bean and it compiles cleanly.  When I got to test
the bean, the following error appears:

java.lang.UnsupportedClassVersionError: foo/EchoTester (Unsupported major.minor
version 49.0)
	at java.lang.ClassLoader.defineClass0(Native Method)
	at java.lang.ClassLoader.defineClass(ClassLoader.java:537)
	at java.security.SecureClassLoader.defineClass(SecureClassLoader.java:123)
	at java.net.URLClassLoader.defineClass(URLClassLoader.java:251)
	at java.net.URLClassLoader.access$100(URLClassLoader.java:55)
	at java.net.URLClassLoader$1.run(URLClassLoader.java:194)
	at java.security.AccessController.doPrivileged(Native Method)
	at java.net.URLClassLoader.findClass(URLClassLoader.java:187)
	at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadClass(ClassLoader.java:289)
	at sun.misc.Launcher$AppClassLoader.loadClass(Launcher.java:274)
	at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadClass(ClassLoader.java:235)
	at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadClassInternal(ClassLoader.java:302)
Exception in thread "main" 


I appears the compiled class file is of a different version than the JRE.  When
I dug a bit deeper, I saw that entries in .settings\org.eclipse.core.jdtprefs
were set to the wrong level.  i.e. org.eclipse.jdt.core.compiler.compliance=1.5

This would explain the incompatible version.

Ok, this could just be a refactoring issue.  Due to my inferior grasp of the
options in the project creation wizard, I accepted the defaults which were Java
5.0 and no runtime target.

Lowering the severity.
Kosta, sending your way, you must be more aware of this.

This happened because the server target runtime ui has not been integrated with 
project facets. It should have prevented you from targeting a Tomcat runtime 
that sits on JRE 1.4 while you project has jst.java 5.0 facet installed. If you 
go through the Add/Remove Project facets ui, you will get the correct behavior. 
In particular, you would not see you tomcat runtime until you change the java 
facet version to 1.4. At which point, you will see the runtime and be able to 
target/bind to it.

Re-assigning to Tim to figure out what should happen to the server target 
runtime properties page. At minimum, it needs to filter based on which facets 
are installed.

Server targets were deprecated since facets started appearing in the builds, and as of M9 don't appear in the API or UI anymore. Another bug was opened for the facets class version issue and has had much discussion offline. Since everything reported here is covered elsewhere or no longer applicable, I am closing this bug.
